content.description:
Slabby face climbing with some horizontals.  This is one of the only good lead climbs at this crag. 

  (I got this name from Tough Schist by Travis Peckham). The route names here are really generic, maybe folks have something better?
content.protection: Mostly small-med cams.  Not a ton of gear but it's pretty good.
content.location: This is 100 feet right of the big perched block.  The start is right in front of a striated boulder.  You just climb up between the two easy-looking cracks, wherever you want.

content.description:
Slabby face climbing with various seams/thin cracks.  This is a fairly wide area and you can climb it wherever you want. 

  (I got this name from Tough Schist by Travis Peckham).  The route names here are really generic, maybe folks have something better?
content.protection: Very little decent gear... I guess that's why it's most popular as a top-rope
content.location: Clear streak right of the perched block.  There is a small corner to start with.

content.description: Left facing corner/flake at far right end of the cliff. Very mellow
content.protection: solo? decent gear potential and trees/boulders up top for TR
content.location: Right end of cliff just left of the climbers trails that go to the top

content.description: Blocky start that becomes more slabby and a bit less featured further up.
content.protection: TR or trad w/ runout slab at the top
content.location: Almost far right end of the main cliff

content.description: Sit start to the right of the tree with matched hands on a sidepull. Continue up and left, arete is off until the top out. Top out is just before you run into the tree. Â
content.protection: Single crash pad should do the trick
content.location: Big vertical boulder at the base of the main crag, there are three similar looking boulders, but this is the largest and the furthest to the climbers right.

content.description:
This is the most popular crag here.  It is slabby and about 80' tall.  Very popular for top-roping by school groups and summer camps.  There are probably 4 or 5 distinct areas of clean rock here but the rock is such that you can basically climb them wherever you want wherever it's clean.  A few climbs do take gear but most don't.  Everything looks to be in the 5.5 to 5.8 range. 

  The trees here have clearly taken a beating from all the top roping.  Be nice to them and use trad anchors wherever possible.
